articles.headline: Oil and Gasoline Prices Begin to Creep Up
articles.snippet: Somewhat upbeat economic data, new tensions in Nigeria and reports that China plans to build up its reserves have lifted crude prices. Gasoline prices have followed.
articles.abstract: Somewhat upbeat economic data, new tensions in Nigeria and reports that China plans to build up its reserves have lifted crude prices. Gasoline prices have followed.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Crude oil and gasoline prices are inching up again.

articles.headline: Bidding War Pits Pfizer And Teva
articles.snippet: Pfizer and two competitors with their eyes on global growth pursue a big maker of generics.
articles.abstract: Pfizer and two competitors with their eyes on global growth pursue a big maker of generics.
articles.lead_paragraph: The executives at some generic drug companies have a new catchphrase: There’s no place like Ulm. There’s no place like Ulm.

articles.headline: Northrop and EADS to Drop Bid for Tanker
articles.snippet: The decision leaves Boeing as the likely winner of a contract that could eventually cost $100 billion.
articles.abstract: The decision leaves Boeing as the likely winner of a contract that could eventually cost $100 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said on Monday that it would not bid for a $40 billion contract to build aerial refueling planes for the Air Force, leaving its rival, Boeing, as the likely winner of one of the Pentagon’s largest contracts.

articles.headline: Google’s Computing Power Refines Translation Tool
articles.snippet: The company’s network pushes the limits of translation technology and has become a favored source for millions.
articles.abstract: The company’s network pushes the limits of translation technology and has become a favored source for millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In a meeting at Google in 2004, the discussion turned to an e-mail message the company had received from a fan in South Korea. Sergey Brin, a Google founder, ran the message through an automatic translation service that the company had licensed.

articles.headline: Mexico Oil Politics Keeps Riches Just Out of Reach
articles.snippet: The country, which kicked out oil firms in 1938, now needs assistance to get its oil out of the ground.
articles.abstract: The country, which kicked out oil firms in 1938, now needs assistance to get its oil out of the ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENUSTIANO CARRANZA, Mexico — To the Mexican people, one of the great achievements in their history was the day their president kicked out foreign oil companies in 1938. Thus, they celebrate March 18 as a civic holiday.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: Public Pension Funds Are Adding Risk to Raise Returns
articles.snippet: Even as big companies are moving their pension funds out of stocks, state governments are chasing higher returns by making riskier investments.
articles.abstract: Even as big companies are moving their pension funds out of stocks, state governments are chasing higher returns by making riskier investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: States and companies have started investing very differently when it comes to the billions of dollars they are safeguarding for workers’ retirement.

articles.headline: Senate Panel to Investigate Deaths at Long-Term Care Facilities
articles.snippet: The investigation will focus on Select Medical, which runs more long-term care facilities than any other company.
articles.abstract: The investigation will focus on Select Medical, which runs more long-term care facilities than any other company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee has opened an investigation into patient deaths and allegations of substandard treatment at long-term care hospitals, small specialty medical centers that treat chronically ill patients.

articles.headline: Solar Industry Learns Lessons in Spanish Sun
articles.snippet: A national commitment to solar power transformed one community but big subsidies led to unsustainable growth.
articles.abstract: A national commitment to solar power transformed one community but big subsidies led to unsustainable growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUERTOLLANO, Spain — Two years ago, this gritty mining city hosted a brief 21st-century gold rush. Long famous for coal, Puertollano discovered another energy source it had overlooked: the relentless, scorching sun.

articles.headline: In Chile’s Capital, Damage Is Inside and Invisible
articles.snippet: Santiago’s streets appear mostly unscathed, but many people do not know if their lives will ever be the same.
articles.abstract: Santiago’s streets appear mostly unscathed, but many people do not know if their lives will ever be the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — From outside, there is no sign that the century-old building where Cecilia Painaqueo lived with her four children was damaged by one of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded. But inside her second-floor apartment, the bedroom walls collapsed and the wooden ceiling buckled.

articles.headline: Oscar Winners Try to Keep Whale Off Sushi Plates
articles.snippet: The team behind “The Cove” set up a sting operation at a restaurant that officials say served illegal whale meat.
articles.abstract: The team behind “The Cove” set up a sting operation at a restaurant that officials say served illegal whale meat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It is sport among black belt sushi eaters here to see just how daring one’s palate can be. But even among the squid-chomping, roe-eating and uni-nibbling fans, whale is almost unheard of on the plate. It also happens to be illegal.

articles.headline: So Where’s Consumer Protection?
articles.snippet: Should a consumer protection agency have true independence, as many Democrats believe it should, so that it has real power to act on its own?
articles.abstract: Should a consumer protection agency have true independence, as many Democrats believe it should, so that it has real power to act on its own?
articles.lead_paragraph: If six of the biggest banking industry lobbying groups are in perfect lockstep on an issue, do they most likely have the best interests of consumers at heart?
